awd_titl_txt: RII Track-1: Linking Microbial Life to Ecosystem Services Across Wyoming's Dynamic Landscape
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-technical Description
Microbial organisms are ubiquitous and abundant in soil and aquatic environments. One teaspoon of soil may contain over a billion bacteria, belonging to thousands of distinct species. These organisms play essential roles in cycling nutrients, decomposing organic matter, and determining the fate of pollutants released by human activities. This project will collect samples of microbes from thousands of sites across Wyoming that differ in their local climate, land use, and plant life. The samples will be analyzed to better understand the environmental roles of the microbes and their responses to changes in precipitation, soil properties, and land use. Species composition and ecological relationships to the ecosystem will be determined using DNA, RNA, and protein sequencing. Statistical methods will be used to uncover the relationships between microbes and how the overall ecosystems function. The results will help predict how different regions will respond to environmental disturbances and provide policy makers tools to better manage natural resources. The project will also train workers in how to handle the huge volumes of data generated by such research; these skills will be transferrable to many sectors of the Wyoming economy. Outreach efforts to Native American, Latino, and hearing-impaired students will promote diversification of the workforce trained in STEM fields.

Technical Description 
The overarching aims of this project are to advance process-based understanding of soil and freshwater microbiomes, to develop cutting-edge data-science training and research and development capacity in Wyoming, and to position the University of Wyoming as a national leader in microbial ecology and data science. To define the causal factors that determine microbial distributions, over nineteen thousand samples of soil-, water-, and plant-associated microbes will be collected and processed, taking advantage of environmental gradients that exist across the state. Samples will be studied using a variety of ?omic? (genomic, transcriptomic, proteomic, metabolomic) and biogeochemical technologies, including enzymatic assays and stable isotope probing. Relationships between microbial life and ecological consequences will be modeled and tested by statistical and experimental means. Investments in equipment infrastructure, inter-disciplinary training for diverse students and postdocs, and new faculty hires will enhance the research capacity of Wyoming. The focus on data science training will serve the technology workforce needs of Wyoming and benefit the state economy.

por.por_cntn:
The six-year-long Microbial Ecology Collaborative (Micro) project, which ran from September 1, 2017, to August 31, 2023, has concluded, marking a significant milestone in advancing Wyoming's national and international reputation in microbial ecology, data science, and collaboration with indigenous communities. Through NSF EPSCoR funding, this groundbreaking project has not only achieved its goals but also paved the way for Wyoming's emergence as a key player in these fields.

A strategic plan steered the project through nearly 90 distinct activities categorized across six Research and Project Element Thrusts. The primary objective was to bolster Wyoming's prominence in microbial ecology and related disciplines, especially data science. Remarkably, over 90% of these activities were fully accomplished or surpassed, while the remaining elements significantly contributed to meeting the core scientific objectives.

Within the Micro project, scientists authored 60 peer-reviewed journal articles and secured an impressive $52 million in federal and state grants and over $500 thousand in private financial backing. Research findings were diverse and impactful, ranging from the revelation of higher microbial diversity in biofilms versus planktonic aquatic communities to uncovering soil organic matter recovery patterns post-grazing, along with culturing extremophiles from rock microbiomes. Additional discoveries were made in the organic molecules supplied by roots that improve soils and their microbial communities, the microbial mediation of nitrogen cycles in semiarid shrublands, and the adverse effects of herbicides on soil fungi. The project investigated the intricate differences between prokaryotic and eukaryotic microbial community assemblages and even delved into utilizing microbial membrane properties to decode paleoclimate signals in soils and lakes.

The project's broader impacts are also noteworthy. Micro fostered successful collaborations with the Wind River Indian Reservation (WRIR), engaging in micro-grant projects facilitated by Central Wyoming Community College. These endeavors included initiatives promoting new business development through entrepreneurship training. Additionally, Western Ecosystems Technology, Inc., a private Wyoming-based company, organized several workshops on environmental data science and offered valuable opportunities to undergraduate and graduate interns in the field of data science.

Micro is poised for ongoing, sustainable success, highlighted by the recruitment of four faculty members engaged in independent research, all of who are now supported by external funding. Moreover, numerous faculty associated with Micro secured new grants leveraging data generated during the Micro project. The two Micro core labs, specializing in genome technology and biogeochemistry, operate on a cost recovery model and will continue internal and external sample collection through the University of Wyoming (UW). A data science center within the new UW School of Computing facilitates collaboration between academics and industry professionals, cementing Micro's enduring impact.

The Microbial Ecology Collaborative has propelled Wyoming into the global spotlight in microbial ecology, data science, and collaborative indigenous partnerships, setting a benchmark for interdisciplinary research and community engagement.

 


Last Modified: 12/13/2023
Modified by: Brent Ewers

Images (1 of )
  • Major changes in dominant zooplankton relative abundances - as recorded by sedimentary DNA - in two adjacent mountain lakes in the Wind River Range, Wyoming. Both lakes were naturally fishless, but fish were stocked in Footprint lake in the late 1920's.
    Jordan Von Eggers, University of Wyoming
    Copyrighted
    Brent Ewers
    Zooplankton records in Wyoming's Wind River Range
  • A novel rock dwelling Actinobacterium isolated from a Badland surface in Wyoming Red Desert
    Seifeddine Ben Tekaya, University of Wyoming
    Copyrighted
    Brent Ewers
    Novel Geodermatophilus sp.
  • A picture of the Pat Guthrie Special Exhibitions Teach Gallery at the University of Wyoming. The works of Micrographia, resulting from the Microbestiary Artist Residency are shown in full.
    Micrographia, Microbestiary Outreach Project Lead Erin Bentley. Featuring artists Tristan Duke, Reza Safavi, Dr. Andi Wolfe, and the Optics Division of Metabolic Studios.
    Copyrighted
    Brent Ewers
    Microbestiary Exhibit at University of Wyoming
